headline.main: 51 WINNERS FOR THE FOURTH OF JULY

results.snippet: Several weeks ago, Mary Ellen Ruppert stood before her fourth graders and made an announcement as big as any ever heard at St. Maria Goretti School in Madison, Wis.: 10-year-old Jason Verhelst had won the state's Statue of Liberty essay contest.  ...

byline.original: By Michael Winerip, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, Mary Ellen Ruppert stood before her fourth graders and made an announcement as big as any ever heard at St. Maria Goretti School in Madison, Wis.: 10-year-old Jason Verhelst had won the state's Statue of Liberty essay contest. Jason would be going to New York for the Fourth of July. First there was applause. Then the entire fourth grade gave him a standing ovation. Then his teacher led him from classroom to classroom, making the announcement again and again. From kindergarten right up to eighth grade, it was a day of standing ovations for Jason.

results.snippet: CORRIGAN, by Caroline Blackwood. (Penguin, $5.95.) Devina Blunt, a reclusive widow in the English village of Coombe Abbot, is captivated by a flirtatious invalid in this novel by the Irish writer Caroline Blackwood. In The Book Review last year,...
results.lead_paragraph: CORRIGAN, by Caroline Blackwood. (Penguin, $5.95.) Devina Blunt, a reclusive widow in the English village of Coombe Abbot, is captivated by a flirtatious invalid in this novel by the Irish writer Caroline Blackwood. In The Book Review last year, Carolyn Gaiser called the book ''a charming tour de force'' and a ''delightfully ingenious variation on a familiar story - the aging widow preyed upon by a charming confidence man.'' AGATHA CHRISTIE, by Janet Morgan. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) This biography of the celebrated mystery writer ''is a vigorous, lucid and highly readable book that will tell Christie fans what they have long wanted to know,'' Antonia Fraser wrote in these pages in 1985. Ungar has issued THE NEW BEDSIDE, BATHTUB & ARMCHAIR COMPANION TO AGATHA CHRISTIE (Paper, $12.95; Cloth, $25), an expanded and updated edition of its Baedeker of Christieana, with essays on Christie's work as well as synopses of the novels, plays and short-story collections. In 1979 our reviewer called it ''a grand memory book.'' STANLEY ELKIN'S THE MAGIC KINGDOM, by Stanley Elkin. (Obelisk/Dutton, $8.95.) Eddy Bale, mourning the loss of his 12-year-old son, leads a group of terminally ill children on a trip from England to Disney World. The novel's comic vision ''is both hysterical and profound,'' Max Apple said here last year. ''Part sick joke, part lyrical meditation on the nature of disease, the journey to this magic kingdom earns its place among the dark voyages that fiction must take.''

results.snippet: It was a moment so laden with emotion that it choked the voice of Mary Hatwood Futrell, president of the National Education Association, and had many of the more than 7,500 people present dabbing their eyes with handkerchiefs or quietly crying.  ...

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: It was a moment so laden with emotion that it choked the voice of Mary Hatwood Futrell, president of the National Education Association, and had many of the more than 7,500 people present dabbing their eyes with handkerchiefs or quietly crying. The moment came just a year after Christa McAuliffe, America's first ''teacher astronaut,'' was introduced to thousands of her proud and jubilant colleagues at last summer's N.E.A. convention in Washington. Mrs. McAuliffe was an active N.E.A. member and had served as president of her union local near Concord, N. H. Now the N.E.A., the nation's largest teachers' union, was once again honoring Mrs. McAuliffe, this time posthumously. Many of her fellow teachers at the union convention here wore T-shirts or buttons carrying Mrs. McAuliffe's motto, ''I touch the future, I teach.'' Her two children were present, as was her husband, who chose the convention to make his first major public statement since the space shuttle Challenger exploded Jan. 28, killing his wife and the six other crew members.

results.snippet: Liberty Weekend's revelers generated so much trash that the four-day event has entered the Garbage Hall of Fame.   According to the Sanitation Department, the celebration joined the Top 5 list of all-time great garbage-generators, bumping the...
results.lead_paragraph: Liberty Weekend's revelers generated so much trash that the four-day event has entered the Garbage Hall of Fame. According to the Sanitation Department, the celebration joined the Top 5 list of all-time great garbage-generators, bumping the former No. 5, the ticker-tape parade for the Iranian hostages on Jan. 30, 1981.

headline.main: ACTING: THE METHOD AND MYSTIQUE OF JACK NICHOLSON

results.snippet: JACK NICHOLSON IS SINGING ''Three Blind Mice'' for his visitor. Actually, singing might be the wrong word for the eerie droning intonations he's producing; it sounds more like ritual chanting.   Nicholson is emitting these strange sounds while...

byline.original: By Ron Rosenbaum; Ron Rosenbaum's collection of nonfiction, ''Manhattan Passions,'' is to be published in January by Beech Tree/William Morrow

results.lead_paragraph: JACK NICHOLSON IS SINGING ''Three Blind Mice'' for his visitor. Actually, singing might be the wrong word for the eerie droning intonations he's producing; it sounds more like ritual chanting. Nicholson is emitting these strange sounds while standing in the middle of the living room of his home on top of one of the Hollywood Hills - a hilltop he shares with Marlon Brando, although Brando's house is on somewhat higher ground. In order to generate these particular noises, Nicholson has assumed a posture that suggests his post-shock-treatment mode in ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.'' His arms hang limply at his sides, his shoulders droop into a posture that verges on the simian. His jaw is slack, his face drained of expression. To his left, out beyond the glass wall of his living room, the canyons of Hollywood are beginning to redden with the sunset. To his right, on the opposite wall, is one of his Picassos - an interesting early Cubist work that looks to be a painting of a painting of a woman. And from Nicholson's middle comes pouring out, in deep, resonant, utterly uninflected, cello tones: THREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE . . . . BLIIIIIIIINNNNNNDDDDD . . . . MIIIIIIIIIIIICCCCCCCCE . . . .

results.snippet: WILL the medium-format camera stage a comeback? For a time after World War II, this camera -smaller and more flexible than the 4x5 and bigger but slower in operation than the 35-millimeter - was the center of photographic attention. Small enough...
results.lead_paragraph: WILL the medium-format camera stage a comeback? For a time after World War II, this camera -smaller and more flexible than the 4x5 and bigger but slower in operation than the 35-millimeter - was the center of photographic attention. Small enough for use by fast-moving journalists, it produced a quality image that held up well against 4-by-5 film. What slowed the medium-format camera's progress? Designers of 35-millimeter cameras began producing lighter, smaller bodies with a great variety of sharp, fast, quality lenses. In addition, film producers added quality films like 35-millimeter Kodachrome to gadget bags. New versatility and greater image quality for 35-millimeter eclipsed the medium-format cameras, the best-known of which produced 2 1/4-by-2 1/4 images on 120 roll film.

headline.main: AGENCY DELAYS SHUTTLE FLIGHTS UNTIL EARLY '88 NASA'S SHUTTLE MILESTONES March 1986: Review of items deemed critical to shuttle safety begun.   July: George A. Rodney appointed new associate administrator for safety, reliability and quality assurance.   Late July: NASA to propose new configuration for solid-fuel booster rocket for four full-scale tests.   Aug. 15: Recommendations on shuttle program management to be completed.   August: Recommendations on rate of flights to be submitted. The National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, to announce independent panel to audit the adequacy of NASA's review of items critical to shuttle safety.   Sept. 1: Shuttle safety panel to be established.   September: Changes in management of shuttle program to be decided. Preliminary review of design of solid-fuel booster rocket to be finished.   November: Proposal for changes in cargo scheduling policy to be submitted to NASA headquarters.   December: Final decisions on crew escape system to be reached.   Dec. 31: Review of every aspect of NASA management by Gen. Samuel C. Phillips, U.S.A.F., retired, to be completed.   March 1987: Review of design of solid-fuel booster rocket and review of requirements for maintenance tests and checkouts to be completed.   May: Review of NASA headquarters organization and hazard analysis to be completed.   June: NASA to submit one-year report to the President.   August: New brakes for shuttle orbiter to be delivered.   December: Review to certify design of solid-fuel rocket booster to be completed.   January to March 1988: Earliest date for launching.

results.snippet: The space agency said today that the earliest date the space shuttle could resume flying would be in early 1988, a substantial delay from the previous goal of July 1987.   In a report requested by President Reagan, the agency also indicated it...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space agency said today that the earliest date the space shuttle could resume flying would be in early 1988, a substantial delay from the previous goal of July 1987. In a report requested by President Reagan, the agency also indicated it hoped to redesign the booster rockets so that existing hardware can be used. Problems with the booster rockets caused the Jan. 28 Challenger disaster in which the crew of seven died. But as a contingency, should this equipment prove unable to pass tests and safety reviews, the agency said it would also develop concepts for ''a totally new design that does not utilize existing hardware.''

headline.main: DIVERS SAW FLIGHT SUIT IN SHUTTLE WRECK

results.snippet: An astronaut flight suit, caught in wreckage 87 feet below the ocean's surface, was the marker that told two divers from Cocoa Beach that they had found the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin, the divers say.   The divers, Mike McAllister and...
results.lead_paragraph: An astronaut flight suit, caught in wreckage 87 feet below the ocean's surface, was the marker that told two divers from Cocoa Beach that they had found the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin, the divers say. The divers, Mike McAllister and Terry Bailey, who work for Petchem Inc., an Air Force contractor, recall picking their way through a mass of mangled metal when they saw the spacesuit.

headline.main: ASTRONAUT'S FAMILY SEEKS $15 MILLION FROM NASA

results.snippet: The family of Michael J. Smith, the Navy commander who piloted the shuttle Challenger on its catastrophic final mission, has filed a $15 million negligence claim against the space agency and a key employee.   The claim charges that the National...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The family of Michael J. Smith, the Navy commander who piloted the shuttle Challenger on its catastrophic final mission, has filed a $15 million negligence claim against the space agency and a key employee. The claim charges that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and several of its employees should have known that ''a catastrophic accident would likely occur'' and had failed to take action to prevent it. The space agency will have six months to decide how to handle the claim, which was dated July 2 and filed with the space agency under the Federal Tort Claims Act. The claim is the first by survivors of the Challenger crew's of seven, killed in the disaster Jan. 28. An investigation by a Presidential commission uncovered and described in detail numerous errors and misjudgments by the space agency and its chief rocket builder that led to the accident.

headline.main: Push Is Coming To Shove for Iacocca

results.snippet: The 1988 Presidential sweepstakes began in 1985, so it should not be surprising that in the summer of 1986 the search for a fresh face is already under way.   Some Democrats think they have found their man in Lee Iacocca, the Italian immigrants'...
results.lead_paragraph: The 1988 Presidential sweepstakes began in 1985, so it should not be surprising that in the summer of 1986 the search for a fresh face is already under way. Some Democrats think they have found their man in Lee Iacocca, the Italian immigrants' son who shared center stage with Lady Liberty at the statue's centennial celebration. He is not only a fresh face, they say, but a political outsider, a folk hero, a supersalesman and the embodiment of the American dream all rolled into one political package. In public opinion polls, Americans say they respect only President Reagan and the Pope more than they respect Mr. Iacocca.

results.snippet: Two Soviet astronauts returned to earth today after a four-month mission that included the first flight between two space stations and the construction of a 50-foot tower as practice for creating large structures in space.   The return of the Soyuz...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two Soviet astronauts returned to earth today after a four-month mission that included the first flight between two space stations and the construction of a 50-foot tower as practice for creating large structures in space. The return of the Soyuz T-15 capsule, which landed in a field in the southern republic of Kazakhstan, was televised. According to the official Soviet press agency Tass, the craft touched down at 4:34 P.M. about 33 miles northeast of the city of Arkalyk. The two astronauts, Col. Leonid D. Kizim, 44 years old, and Vladimir A. Solovyov, 39, looked tired and serious as they sat in low chairs and were interviewed by Soviet state television soon after landing. Both men are space veterans, having set a endurance record of 238 days in space in 1984 with a third astronaut. Tass said Colonel Kizim, the commander, and Mr. Solovyov, the flight engineer, were in good health.

headline.main: EX-SHUTTLE ROCKET CHIEF QUITS SPACE AGENCY

results.snippet: Lawrence B. Mulloy, who directed the space shuttle's solid rocket booster program at the time of the Challenger disaster, announced today that he would retire from the space agency at the end of the week.   Mr. Mulloy drew criticism in recent...
results.lead_paragraph: Lawrence B. Mulloy, who directed the space shuttle's solid rocket booster program at the time of the Challenger disaster, announced today that he would retire from the space agency at the end of the week. Mr. Mulloy drew criticism in recent months for his actions before the Challenger disaster Jan. 28, in which the seven crew members died. He has said ''system failure'' rather than individuals were to blame for the disaster.

headline.main: ASTRONAUTS ASSERT NASA PLAN TO BUILD SPACE STATION IS FLAWED

results.snippet: Astronauts have raised strong objections in an internal memorandum to the design of the planned $8 billion space station, complaining that it would be too complex to be assembled in orbit by space-walking crews, lacked emergency escape systems and...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts have raised strong objections in an internal memorandum to the design of the planned $8 billion space station, complaining that it would be too complex to be assembled in orbit by space-walking crews, lacked emergency escape systems and had inadequate living quarters. The memorandum, obtained by the magazine Aviation Week and Space Technology, said that ''program morale is poor'' and ''people do not believe in this station.'' Space agency officials confirmed that astronauts had prepared a memorandum about their complaints for presentation June 20 to the project manager at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. The memorandum was written by C. Gordon Fullerton, an experienced shuttle astronaut, but reflected the views of other astronauts as well as middle-level managers of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

results.snippet: While the American space program tries to recover from setbacks that have left dozens of missions on hold and all major rocket systems grounded, the Soviet Union is pressing ahead in a vigorous bid for pre-eminence in the heavens.   Already this...

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: While the American space program tries to recover from setbacks that have left dozens of missions on hold and all major rocket systems grounded, the Soviet Union is pressing ahead in a vigorous bid for pre-eminence in the heavens. Already this year the Soviet Union has conducted more than 40 major launchings, established a large new space station and achieved a space-age first by ferrying astronauts between stations in orbit. Last week they moved a step closer to their goal of a permanent manned presence in space by completing a four-month mission. And in interviews last week Soviet space planners, scientists and experts outlined an ambitious series of ventures meant to stretch well into the next century. In the future, Soviet engineers hope to inaugurate a new generation of rockets, an advanced space shuttle and the first large space-based radio telescope. And Soviet planetary scientists, fresh from celebrating a successful flight past Halley's Comet, are planning a series of unmanned probes toward Venus, the Martian moon Phobos, and beyond.

headline.main: CHALLENGER CREW KNEW OF PROBLEM, DATA NOW SUGGEST

results.snippet: The Challenger crew members were probably aware that the space shuttle was in trouble in the final seconds before it disintegrated and may well have survived the initial breakup, according to evidence made public today.   The National Aeronautics...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Challenger crew members were probably aware that the space shuttle was in trouble in the final seconds before it disintegrated and may well have survived the initial breakup, according to evidence made public today. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which had previously said the crew was unaware of the impending disaster, made public a transcript of tape recordings in the Jan. 28 flight's final seconds that provided ''the first potential indication,'' the agency said, that the crew knew the accident was occurring. According to the transcript, the last recorded communication by any of the astronauts was the comment ''uh oh,'' made by the pilot, Michael J. Smith, 73 seconds after launching, just after the shuttle lurched and before it broke up in flames. Breathing Supplies Activated NASA also disclosed that at least three of the seven individual emergency breathing supplies on the shuttle had been manually activated, indicating that the astronauts were struggling to survive in the spacecraft's final moments. There were indications that one of the packs could not have been turned on by the person using it, and that one of his companions turned it on for him.

headline.main: Russians and Americans On Midwest Peace Tour

results.snippet: The stern-wheeler Delta Queen carried 47 citizens of the Soviet Union into Dubuque today, one stop on a peace cruise down the Mississippi River.
results.lead_paragraph: The stern-wheeler Delta Queen carried 47 citizens of the Soviet Union into Dubuque today, one stop on a peace cruise down the Mississippi River.
